message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The defect described in the question is ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes left-to-right shunting of blood and an increase in blood flow to the lungs. After successful repair, the left atrial and ventricular pressures are expected to decrease, and the right ventricular pressure is expected to decrease as well due to decreased pulmonary blood flow. Therefore, the correct answer is (B), which indicates a decrease in left atrial pressure, an increase in left ventricular pressure, and a decrease in right ventricular pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cardiac defect described is a ventricular septal defect (VSD) which causes an abnormal flow of blood between the left and right ventricles of the heart. The surgical closure of the VSD results in a decrease in left atrial pressure and an increase in left ventricular pressure. However, the right ventricular pressure decreases due to the reversal of the shunt. Therefore, the expected changes after successful repair of this cardiac defect are a decrease in left atrial pressure, an increase in left ventricular pressure, and a decrease in right ventricular pressure, which is represented by option (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the defect suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes left-to-right shunting of blood during systole. After surgical closure of the defect, the left atrial pressure will decrease due to the decrease in left-to-right shunting, while the left ventricular pressure will increase to compensate for the workload previously shared with the right ventricle. The right ventricular pressure will also decrease due to the decrease in volume overload. Therefore, the expected set of changes is a decrease in left atrial pressure, an increase in left ventricular pressure, and a decrease in right ventricular pressure; option (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described cardiac defect is a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes increased blood flow from the Left Ventricle to the Right Ventricle. After successful repair, there will be a decrease in pressure in the Left Atrium due to less volume overload, leading to a decrease in Left Ventricular pressure. However, the Right Ventricular pressure will still be slightly elevated due to changes in the pulmonary artery pressures. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) - a decrease in Left Atrial pressure, an increase in Left Ventricular pressure, and a decrease in Right Ventricular pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described defect is a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes increased blood flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle. This increased flow leads to increased pressure in the right ventricle and lungs, causing the symptoms described. After successful repair of the defect, there will be a decrease in left-to-right shunting and a subsequent decrease in right ventricular pressure, leading to a decrease in overall pulmonary vascular resistance. As a result, there will be a decrease in left atrial pressure, as the blood is now flowing primarily to the left side of the heart. However, there will initially be an increase in left ventricular pressure, as the left ventricle adjusts to the decreased volume of blood in the right ventricle. Therefore, the correct answer is (B): ↓ left atrial pressure, ↑ left ventricular pressure, and ↓ right ventricular pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cardiac defect described is a ventricular septal defect (VSD). After successful repair of the defect, there will be a decrease in left atrial pressure and an increase in left ventricular pressure as the left ventricle no longer has to pump blood through the VSD. However, there will be a decrease in right ventricular pressure as the right ventricle no longer has to overwork to pump blood through the defect. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) with a decrease in left atrial pressure, an increase in left ventricular pressure, and a decrease in right ventricular pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given scenario describes a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which results in left-to-right shunting of blood and can eventually lead to pulmonary hypertension. After successful closure of the VSD, the left atrial pressure is expected to decrease, as there is no longer a left-to-right shunt, while the left ventricular pressure is expected to increase due to improved contractility. However, the right ventricular pressure is expected to decrease as there is now less blood flow from the left side of the heart into the pulmonary circulation. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) ↓ ↑ ↓.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given symptoms suggest that the patient has a ventricular septal defect (VSD) that leads to left-to-right shunting of blood. After successful repair of the defect, the left atrial pressure is expected to decrease as the left-to-right shunt is eliminated. However, the left ventricular pressure is expected to increase as it has been compensating for the shunt. The right ventricular pressure is expected to decrease as the increased pulmonary resistance caused by the shunt is relieved. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) ↓ ↑ ↓.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh holosystolic murmur and soft mid-diastolic rumble suggest ventricular septal defect. After successful repair, the left atrial pressure will decrease due to the decrease in left-to-right shunt, while the left ventricular pressure will increase to maintain cardiac output. The right ventricular pressure will also decrease since there is no longer increased pulmonary flow. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) ↓ ↑ ↓.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described cardiac defect is a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt and increased blood flow and pressure on the right side of the heart. After successful closure of the defect, the left-to-right shunt will decrease or stop, leading to decreased blood flow and pressure on the right side of the heart. This will cause a decrease in left atrial pressure due to decreased left-to-right shunting and an increase in left ventricular pressure due to the increased workload. Right ventricular pressure will decrease due to decreased blood flow from the left-to-right shunt. Therefore, the expected changes are a decrease in left atrial pressure, an increase in left ventricular pressure, and a decrease in right ventricular pressure. Option (B) is the correct answer.
